snippet: Unlike the Soviet Union, today’s Russia has substantial trade ties with Western Europe, and it and the West are more dependent on each other than they were in decades past.
abstract: Floyd Norris Off the Charts column holds that as Western countries discuss economic measures against Russia, they confront a country where growth was slowing and whose currency and stock markets were weak every before the Ukraine crisis erupted; notes that Russia's manufacturers are no longer doing as well as their neighbors, and industrial production has been weak, relative to the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the Soviet Union, today’s Russia has substantial trade ties with Western Europe, and it and the West are more dependent on each other than they were in decades past.

headline.print_headline: New Cold War Would Differ From Old
headline.main: New Cold War Would Differ From Old
